Description: Stamp (vessel): half-qisṭan. Five line Kufic inscription. Semicircle with a dot in it pointing upwards at end of legend. Made of green glass.
Curator's comments: From the same die: Petrie, W.M.F. 1926. ‘Glass stamps and weights’. London, 124; Dudzus, Wolfgang. 1961. Frühe Umayyadische Glasstempel aus Ägypten mit Beamtennamen in den Berliner Museen. ‘Staatliche Museen zu Berlin’ 3-4. Berlin, 6b; Balog, P. 1976. ‘Ummayad, ʿAbbasid and Ṭūlūnid glass weights and vessel-stamps’. New York, 161. Cf. Balog 1976, 159-60.

The alif at the end of qisṭ still requires explanation; it could be an accusative, but, if so, is ungrammatical. Miles was probably right to suggest that it is a variant form of a loan-word. Qīrāt also a borrowing from Greek, occasionally occurs with a similar final aiif (e.g. on OA+ 4261).
Bibliographic references: Morton 1985 / A Catalogue of Early Islamic Glass Stamps (101)
